TEXT.English: A "madrassa" is an Arabic institute of higher learning, usually religious in nature. The earliest madrasses were formed in Islamic mosques, where scholars gathered to study and debate religious and secular issues of the day. Over time students would come to study with the most learned scholars; the most popular teachers often had to construct separate buildings to hold their growing student population.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]At the madrassas the students would learn to read and write and study religious doctrine, history and law. Some madrassas also taught logic, world history, foreign language, mathematics, art and science. Since state-run colleges and universities did not appear until later in history, the madrassas were critical centers of learning in many early Arabic cities.

TEXT.English: A "pavilion" is a covered building without surrounding walls (think of it as a roof supported by columns). This kind of structure has been extremely popular for centuries in China, where they are often found in parks and gardens as well as in temple complexes. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The first Chinese pavilions were probably constructed during the "Zhou dynasty," and they became quite numerous during the Warring States Period (approximately 400-200 BC). At first these buildings may have been used as watchtowers, providing soldiers with an uninterrupted 360-degree view along with shelter from rain and snow, but in later periods they were incorporated into Chinese gardens and parks, where they were prized for their elegance and simplicity of design.

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Â XVI-XVII âåêàõ ôðàíöóçñêèå àðèñòîêðàòû ââåëè òðàäèöèþ ñîáèðàòüñÿ â êðóæîê äëÿ îáñóæäåíèÿ ëèòåðàòóðíûõ è õóäîæåñòâåííûõ íîâèíîê. Ñëîâî "ñàëîí" ïðîèçîøëî îò íàçâàíèÿ êîìíàòû, â êîòîðîé ïðîõîäèëè ñîáðàíèÿ. Êàê ïðàâèëî, ñàëîíû óñòðàèâàëèñü ïðåêðàñíåéøèìè, èíòåëëèãåíòíûìè è ñîñòîÿòåëüíûìè ïðåäñòàâèòåëüíèöàìè ôðàíöóçñêîãî äâîðÿíñòâà. Â XVII âåêå ïîÿâèëèñü äâà íàèáîëåå èçâåñòíûõ ñàëîíà - îäèí âåëà ìàäàì äå Ðàìáóëüå, äðóãîé - åå çàêëÿòàÿ ïîäðóãà Ìàäëåí äå Ñêóäåðè. TEXT.English: In the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, the French nobility used to gather the local "intelligentsia" to discuss the literary or artistic works of the day. The word "salon" refers to the reception room where these parties were held. The salons were almost always organized by the most beautiful, intelligent and rich women in the French nobility. During the seventeenth centuries the two most important literary salons were run by Madame de Rambouillet and her rival, Madeleine de Scudery. Virtually every important French author, poet, artist and scientist attended one or the other of these gatherings, making them the very centers of French intellectual thought.

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Ñáîðî÷íûé öåõ - ýòî çäàíèå èëè ãðóïïà çäàíèé, ãäå ðàáî÷èå ñîáèðàþò ñëîæíûå ìåõàíèçìû èç ñîñòàâíûõ ÷àñòåé. Âî ìíîãèõ öåõàõ èñïîëüçóåòñÿ êîíâåéåðíàÿ ñèñòåìà: âäîëü äâèæóùåéñÿ ëåíòû ñòîÿò ðàáîòíèêè, êàæäûé èç íèõ âûïîëíÿåò ñâîþ ôóíêöèþ. Ðÿäîì ñî ñáîðî÷íûì öåõîì îáû÷íî ðàñïîëàãàåòñÿ ñêëàä äëÿ õðàíåíèÿ äåòàëåé è ãîòîâûõ ìåõàíèçìîâ.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Õîòÿ Ãåðìàíèÿ îòíîñèòåëüíî ïîçäíî ïðèøëà ê èíäóñòðèàëüíîé ðåâîëþöèè è ìàíóôàêòóðíîìó òðóäó, â íà÷àëå XX âåêà îíà âûøëà íà ëèäèðóþùèå ïîçèöèè ñðåäè ìèðîâûõ ãîñóäàðñòâ. Íà ñåãîäíÿøíèé äåíü íåìåöêèå çàâîäû óäåðæèâàþò ïåðâûå ìåñòà â ìèðå ïî îðãàíèçàöèè òðóäà è êóëüòóðå ïðîèçâîäñòâà.
TEXT.English: An assembly plant is a building or complex of buildings where workers build goods from their component parts, which are created on-the-spot or in factories elsewhere. In many cases the goods are assembled using an "assembly line" style of production in which individual parts are added to the product by a number of workers, each of whom performs his or her actions in sequence as the product moves down the production line. The plant also may include a warehouse to store parts as well as the finished products.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Although a relative latecomer to the Industrial Revolution and manufacturing in general, by the early twentieth century the German plants were among the most efficient in the world. During the First and Second World Wars German plants built thousands of tanks, planes, and other war materiel under horrendous conditions and in the face of concentrated Allied bombing attacks. Into the twenty-first century the German manufactories remain among the world's best.

TEXT.English: Modern western drama was created in Greece around 530 BC, evolving from the "dithyramb," a fertility ritual of songs, poems and dances offered to the Greek god Dionysus. An "Odeon" is a large, open-aired structure in which such performances were held. The audience sat in a semicircle of seats around a central paved "dancing square" (orchestra). The first row of seats was reserved for important officials or priests. There was usually an altar dedicated to Dionysus somewhere in the odeon. The "logeion" was a small raised platform where the performers acted (the original dramas had at most three or four actors; the size of the stage would increase as later plays required bigger casts).

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Áîëüøàÿ ÷àñòü èìïåðèè èíêîâ çàíèìàëà êðóòûå ñêëîíû Àíä. Â òàêèõ óñëîâèÿõ áûëî ñëîæíî ðàçâèâàòü ñåëüñêîå õîçÿéñòâî, ïîñêîëüêó ïîñòîÿííàÿ ýðîçèÿ èñòîùàëà ïî÷âó, à ïðîëèâíûå äîæäè ìîãëè ñìûòü â äîëèíó óðîæàé âìåñòå ñ çåìëåé. Îäíàêî õèòðîóìíûå èíêè íàó÷èëèñü ñòðîèòü òàê íàçûâàåìûå çåìëåäåëü÷åñêèå òåððàñû è âûðàùèâàòü íà íèõ óðîæàé. TEXT.English: Much of the Incan empire was located on the steep slopes of the Andes Mountains. Such terrain posed a significant challenge to agriculture, as constant soil erosion made the ground less fertile, and heavy rains were quite likely to wash away the current crops (as well as the soil they stood on). Very early on, the Incan farmers mastered the art of constructing terraces upon which to grow their crops. These terraces created much flatter ground upon which to farm, which resulted in less soil erosion and greatly increased production.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Creation of farming terraces in such steep terrain required a good deal of engineering skill (to build the necessary retaining walls), as well as an abundance of cheap manual labor and a sophisticated knowledge of irrigation. They were well worth the effort, however, and with them the Incans were able to sustain thriving cities in locations that other civilizations would have found totally inhospitable.

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Ìàâçîëåé - ýòî ìàññèâíîå è áîãàòî óêðàøåííîå çäàíèå, â êîòîðîì çàõîðîíåí ïîëêîâîäåö, ïîëèòè÷åñêèé ëèäåð, èëè íåâåðîÿòíî áîãàòûé êóïåö. Òðàäèöèÿ âîçâåäåíèÿ ýòèõ ìàññèâíûõ ãðîáíèö ñóùåñòâîâàëà âî ìíîãèõ äðåâíèõ öèâèëèçàöèÿõ. Ìàâçîëåè îáû÷íî èãðàëè ðîëü ðåëèãèîçíûõ ïàìÿòíèêîâ è ïîëèòè÷åñêè âàæíûõ îáúåêòîâ - âíóøàÿ ëþäÿì ïî÷òåíèå è ñòðàõ ïåðåä ìîãóùåñòâîì ãîñóäàðñòâà è âàæíîñòüþ óñîïøåãî. Åãèïåòñêèå ïèðàìèäû - ñàìûå êðóïíûå ìàâçîëåè íà Çåìëå.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Íà ïðîòÿæåíèè âåêîâ èíäèéñêèå âëàñòèòåëè ñòðîèëè ìàâçîëåè äëÿ ñåáÿ è ñâîèõ ðîäñòâåííèêîâ. Èçâåñòíåéøèì èç èíäèéñêèõ ìàâçîëååâ ÿâëÿåòñÿ Òàäæ-Ìàõàë, âîçâåäåííûé â ñåìíàäöàòîì âåêå ïî ïðèêàçó èìïåðàòîðà Âåëèêèõ Ìîãîëîâ Øàõ-Äæàõàíà â ïàìÿòü î ëþáèìîé æåíå Ìóìòàç-Ìàõàë.
TEXT.English: A "mausoleum" is a large and ornate building constructed to hold the remains of a person of importance, typically a leader, warlord, or extremely wealthy merchant. Mausoleums can be found in many ancient civilizations, where they played both a sacred and political role - seeking to awe the viewer with the power and wealth of the state (or the individual). The Egyptian pyramids are essentially huge mausoleums built to hold the remains of pharaohs.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Throughout history Indian leaders have constructed extensive mausoleums for themselves and their relatives. Perhaps the best known of these is the Taj Mahal, built in the seventeenth century by the Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan to house the remains of his beloved wife, Mumtaz Mahal.

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Â íà÷àëå XX âåêà ßïîíèÿ ñòàëà îäíîé èç âåäóùèõ ïðîìûøëåííûõ äåðæàâ. Êàê ñëåäñòâèå, åé ïîñòîÿííî òðåáîâàëîñü òîïëèâî äëÿ ìíîãî÷èñëåííûõ çàâîäîâ, ýëåêòðîñòàíöèé è òðàíñïîðòà, îñîáåííî ìîðñêîãî. Áîëüøèíñòâî êîëîíèçàòîðñêèõ óñèëèé ßïîíèè òîãî ïåðèîäà áûëî íàïðàâëåíî íà çàõâàò èñòî÷íèêîâ ðåñóðñîâ. Êîíôëèêò ìåæäó ßïîíèåé è ÑØÀ - âòîðîé òèõîîêåàíñêîé äåðæàâîé - áûë òàêæå ðàçâÿçàí íà ïî÷âå êîíòðîëÿ íàä ðåñóðñàìè è ñòàë îäíîé èç ïðåäïîñûëîê âòîðîé ìèðîâîé âîéíû (èëè, ïî êðàéíåé ìåðå, ïðèâåë ê îòêðûòèþ òèõîîêåàíñêîãî òåàòðà âîåííûõ äåéñòâèé).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Ñëàíåö - ýòî ìàòåðèàë, ñîñòîÿùèé èç ñëîåâ ïåðåãíèâøèõ è ñïðåññîâàííûõ âåùåñòâ îðãàíè÷åñêîãî ïðîèñõîæäåíèÿ. Äëÿ âûðàáîòêè òîïëèâà èç ñëàíöà íåîáõîäèì ãîðàçäî áîëåå òðóäîåìêèé è äîðîãîñòîÿùèé ïðîöåññ, ÷åì äëÿ ïåðåðàáîòêè íåôòè. Îäíàêî, íå èìåÿ äîñòóïà ê íåôòÿíûì ñêâàæèíàì è ìåñòîðîæäåíèÿì óãëÿ, ÿïîíöû â äîâîåííûé ïåðèîä ïîñòðîèëè ñåòü çàâîäîâ ïî ïåðåðàáîòêå ñëàíöà. Îäèí òàêîé çàâîä â Ìàíü÷æóðèè ïðîèçâîäèë 200 000 òîíí ñëàíöåâîãî òîïëèâà â ãîä. Âî âðåìÿ âîåííûõ äåéñòâèé ñ Ñîåäèíåííûìè øòàòàìè èìåííî ñëàíöåâîå òîïëèâî äåðæàëî ÿïîíñêèå âîåííûå êîðàáëè íà ïëàâó.
TEXT.English: In the early half of the twentieth century, Japan was fast becoming one of the most industrialized nations in the world. As such, Japan needed access to fossil fuels to run her factories, energy plants, and vehicles, especially her growing navy. Much of Japan's colonization/conquest efforts during that period were designed to gain control over areas rich in such resources. Conflict between Japan and the United States - another growing Pacific industrial power - over these resources was one of the root causes of the Second World War (or the Pacific theatre portion of that war, anyway).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Shale is a compound formed of decayed and compacted organic material much like other fossil fuels. However, shale requires a good deal of preparation before it becomes an adequate fuel, making it much more expensive than petroleum. However, lacking easy access to high-quality coal and petroleum during the pre-war period, the Japanese constructed a number of plants designed to create fuel from shale. The shale plant in occupied Manchuria was capable of producing as much as 200,000 tons of shale oil per year. Such plants kept the Japanese navy afloat during its long struggle with the larger and resource-rich United States.

TEXT.English: As nomadic tribesmen (and later as cavalry-based conquerors), the Mongolians' survival was dependent upon the quality of their horses and the skill of their riders. A warhorse must be extensively trained if it is to be successfully used in battle. In their natural state, most horses quite sensibly seek to run away from dangerous situations - say, when surrounded by screaming men armed with sharp objects. A cavalryman's horse, on the other hand, needs to be able to suppress this instinct and instead instantly carry out any order given it by its rider - no matter how suicidal. Such training takes time and skill - for both mount and rider. Mongolian stables - built in the ubiquitous Mongolian yurt (or "ger") tents - provide such training.

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Öåíòðîì ðèìñêîé îáùåñòâåííîé è òîðãîâîé æèçíè áûë ôîðóì - îòêðûòàÿ ïëîùàäü, îêðóæåííàÿ õðàìàìè, ðûíêàìè, ïðàâèòåëüñòâåííûìè ñîîðóæåíèÿìè. TEXT.English: Roman civic and commercial life was largely centered upon the "forum," an open space surrounded by markets, temples, government buildings, and the "rostra," a platform where Romans made political speeches to their fellows. The Roman forums may have been modeled upon the "agoras," which served much the same purposes in earlier Greek cities. The most famous forum is the "Roman Forum," located at the center of the Imperial City, but most other Roman cities had them as well.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Roman Forum in Rome contained a number of very important and beautiful buildings, including temples devoted to Romulus, Saturn and Vesta, several basilicas, and the "Curia Hostilia," which housed the Roman Senate.

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Èñòîðèÿ ðóññêîãî íàó÷íîãî èññëåäîâàíèÿ óõîäèò êîðíÿìè äàëåêî â ïðîøëîå. Âåëèêèé ðóññêèé ó÷åíûé Ìèõàèë Âàñèëüåâè÷ Ëîìîíîñîâ (1711-1765) ñîçäàë Ìîñêîâñêèé ãîñóäàðñòâåííûé óíèâåðñèòåò, îäèí èç êðóïíåéøèõ èññëåäîâàòåëüñêèõ öåíòðîâ â ìèðå. TEXT.English: Russian scientific research has a long and storied history. The great seventeenth century Russian artist and scientist Mikhail Lomonosov (1711-1765) helped create the University of Moscow, one of the great scientific research institutions of the world. Tsar Peter the Great founded the prestigious Russian Academy of Science by decree in 1724.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]When the Communists took over Russia in the early twentieth century they placed great emphasis upon modernizing and industrializing the Soviet Union, and they heavily funded scientific research. Though initially well behind their European and American counterparts, Russian scientists quickly caught up, and in some areas - especially in the theoretical sciences - surpassed their colleagues in the West.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The collapse of the Soviet Union in the latter half of the twentieth century did great damage to scientific research; however, as Russia regains economic strength, it can be expected her scientists, universities and research institutions will once again be among the leaders in the world.

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Íà ïðîòÿæåíèè âñåé âîåííîé èñòîðèè ÷åëîâå÷åñòâà ëþäè ñòðîèëè óêðåïëåíèÿ äëÿ çàùèòû îò âðàãîâ. Óêðåïëåíèÿ âàðüèðîâàëèñü ïî ðàçìåðàì è ñëîæíîñòè êîíñòðóêöèè îò ïðîñòûõ îêîïîâ è ñòåí äî ñðåäíåâåêîâûõ çàìêîâ è çâåçäîîáðàçíûõ êðåïîñòåé, ñïîñîáíûõ âûäåðæàòü àðòèëëåðèéñêóþ àòàêó. Îñòàíêè êðåïîñòåé òîãî ïåðèîäà ðàçáðîñàíû ïî Íîâîìó ñâåòó, îäèí èç íàèáîëåå ÿðêèõ ïðèìåðîâ - Ýëü Êàñòèëüî Ñàí-Ôåëèïå äåëü Ìîððî â Ñàí-Õóàíå, Ïóýðòî-Ðèêî.
TEXT.English: Throughout history, men have built fortified structures to protect themselves from external enemies. These structures have taken many forms over the years, from simple ditches and walls to medieval castles to huge and complex "star" fortresses designed to protect against muskets and cannon. Citadels are large castle-like structures built in or adjacent to cities. They are designed to defend the city against external attack, and (often) to protect the city's rulers against internal revolt.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]During the fifteenth through seventeenth centuries, Spain was a mighty colonial power with cities scattered throughout the Caribbean and Central and South America, providing Spain with (among other things) enormous quantities of silver and gold. These cities were under constant threat of attack, both from European fleets and armies as well as from native uprisings. To protect its possessions, the Spanish built a series of mighty citadels in its most important cities. When properly garrisoned and supplied, these were extremely difficult to capture. Remnants of these Spanish citadels can still be seen throughout the New World - El Castillo San Felipe del Morro, in San Juan, Puerto Rico, is a fine example of Spanish defensive works.

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Ôèíèêèéñêèé ãîðîä Êàðôàãåí áûë ñèëüíîé ìîðñêîé äåðæàâîé ñ òîðãîâûìè ñâÿçÿìè ïî âñåìó Ñðåäèçåìíîìîðñêîìó ïîáåðåæüþ. TEXT.English: Of Phoenician origin, the city-state of Carthage was a mighty sea power, with a trading empire stretching across much of the Mediterranean. Carthage's wealth (and survival) depended upon the quality of its navy and merchant fleet. To protect its fleet from attack and the elements, and to improve and speed construction of new vessels, Carthage constructed two artificial harbors ("cothon") in the city, a massive effort that required the excavation of some 230,000 cubic meters of earth. One harbor was for the merchant fleet; the second was for the Carthaginian navy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]According to ancient historians, "The harbors had communication with each other, and a common entrance from the sea seventy feet wide, which could be closed with iron chains. The first port was for merchant vessels, and here were collected all kinds of ships' tackle. Within the second port was an island, and great quays were set at intervals round both the harbor and the island. These embankments were full of shipyards which had capacity for 220 vessels."

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]"Äóí" - êåëüòñêîå ñëîâî, îçíà÷àþùåå "ôîðò íà õîëìå". Êåëüòû íà÷àëè ñòðîèòü äóíû ïðèìåðíî â VII âåêå äî í.ý., ðàçâàëèíû òåõ ïîñòðîåê ñåé÷àñ ìîæíî íàéòè â Çàïàäíîé Åâðîïå, Àíãëèè, Øîòëàíäèè è Èðëàíäèè. Êàê ïðàâèëî, äóíû èìåëè âèä íåáîëüøèõ ïðèçåìèñòûõ êðåïîñòåé, ñëîæåííûõ èç êàìíÿ íà âåðøèíàõ âîçâûøåííîñòåé. Âîêðóã íåêîòîðûõ èç íèõ áûëè âûêîïàíû ðâû èëè èñêóññòâåííûå îçåðà.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Ñóùåñòâîâàëè è äóíû áîëåå ñëîæíûõ êîíñòðóêöèé. Ïðèìåðîì ìîæåò ñëóæèòü Äóí Êàðëîóýé íà îñòðîâå Ëüþèñ â Øîòëàíäèè. Îí ñîîðóæåí íà õîëìå ðàçìåðîì îêîëî 47 àêðîâ (19 ãåêòàðîâ).
TEXT.English: "Dun" is a Celtic word meaning, "hill-fort." The Celts began constructing duns around the seventh century BC, and remnants can be found scattered across Western Europe, England, Scotland and Ireland. Duns were typically small, squat towers constructed of dry-laid stone on raised, defensible terrain such as hills and promontories. Some were surrounded by ditches or artificial lakes.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]While many hill-forts were primitive and quite small, more extensive and complex Celtic duns have also been discovered. One such example is "Dun Carloway," on the Isle of Lewis, Scotland. This double-walled castle-like structure originally stood some thirteen meters high and fourteen meters in diameter. Maiden Castle in Dorset, England, is an extensive wall and ditch work surmounting a large hill some 47 acres in size.

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Íà ïðîòÿæåíèè âñåé èñòîðèè êîðåéñêîãî ãîñóäàðñòâà ïðàâèòåëè óäåëÿëè áîëüøîå âíèìàíèå îáðàçîâàíèþ. Ïåðâàÿ îáðàçîâàòåëüíàÿ ñèñòåìà áûëà ñîçäàíà â ïåðèîä "Òðåõ öàðñòâ" (57 ã. äî í.ý. - 668 ã. í.ý.). Ýòà ñèñòåìà áûëà ïîçàèìñòâîâàíà ó êèòàéöåâ. Íàöèîíàëüíàÿ êîíôóöèàíñêàÿ àêàäåìèÿ ("Ñîíãþíãâàí"), ïåðâîå ãîñóäàðñòâåííîå îáðàçîâàòåëüíîå ó÷ðåæäåíèå, áûëà ñîçäàíà â 372 ã. í.ý. Â 660 ãîäó ïîÿâèëàñü Íàöèîíàëüíàÿ êîíôóöèàíñêàÿ øêîëà. Â ïåðâûõ êîðåéñêèõ óíèâåðñèòåòàõ óïîð äåëàëè íà èçó÷åíèå êèòàéñêèõ êëàññèêîâ. Êîíôóöèàíñòâî áûëî îäíèì èç îñíîâíûõ ïðåäìåòîâ è îñòàâàëîñü èì äî òåõ ïîð, ïîêà äèíàñòèÿ Êîð¸ íå ïðîâîçãëàñèëà áóääèçì ãîñóäàðñòâåííîé ðåëèãèåé.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Â ñîâðåìåííîé Êîðåå (ïî êðàéíåé ìåðå Þæíîé) îáðàçîâàíèå ïî-ïðåæíåìó â ïî÷åòå. Îêîëî 300 âûñøèõ ó÷åáíûõ çàâåäåíèé, ñðåäè êîòîðûõ åñòü ïðîôåññèîíàëüíûå ó÷èëèùà, êîëëåäæè, óíèâåðñèòåòû è àñïèðàíòóðû, åæåãîäíî ïðèíèìàþò áîëåå 2 ìèëëèîíîâ ñòóäåíòîâ.
TEXT.English: Throughout its history, Korea has always placed great emphasis on education. The first system of formal education was created during the "Three Kingdoms" period (57 BC - 668 AD). This system was loosely based upon the education system used in Korea's northern neighbor, China. The National Confucian Academy (or "seowon"), the first state-run institution of higher learning was founded in 372 AD, and some three hundred years later another university - the National Confucian College - was founded in 660 AD. Early Korean universities emphasized the study of Chinese classics. Confucianism was an important topic of study, and it remained so even after the Koryo Dyansty adopted Buddhism as the state religion.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In modern Korea (at least in the South) education continues to be held in high importance. There are over 300 institutes of higher education - including junior vocational colleges and colleges and universities and graduate schools - in South Korea, with enrollment in excess of two million students.

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Â òþðêñêîé êóëüòóðå áûëî ïðèíÿòî ñëåäèòü çà ãèãèåíîé. Äî èçîáðåòåíèÿ âîäîïðîâîäà òóðêè ñòðîèëè â êðóïíåéøèõ ãîðîäàõ îáùåñòâåííûå ïàðîâûå áàíè (õàììàìû). Ïîíà÷àëó áàíè âîçâîäèëèñü ïðè ìå÷åòÿõ, ïîñêîëüêó ÷èñòîòà òåëà áûëà âàæíà äëÿ ñîáëþäåíèÿ ðåëèãèîçíûõ ðèòóàëîâ, íî ïîçæå èõ ñòàëè ñòðîèòü è îòäåëüíî. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Ó õàììàìîâ áûëî ìíîãî îáùåãî ñ áàíÿìè Ðèìñêîé èìïåðèè è Âèçàíòèè. Õàììàì ñîñòîÿë èç òðåõ îòäåëåíèé: ïàðèëêè, ïðåäáàííèêà è ïðîõëàäíîé êîìíàòû. Õàììàìû ìîãëè ïîñåùàòü êàê ìóæ÷èíû, òàê è æåíùèíû, íî ìûëèñü îíè ïî îòäåëüíîñòè.
TEXT.English: Cleanliness was extremely important in Ottoman culture. Before modern plumbing, the Ottomans constructed communal steam baths ("hammams") throughout their major cities. In early times many of these were attached to mosques - ritual cleanliness played an important part in the Ottoman religious beliefs - in later periods they evolved into separate buildings and eventually, into enormous complexes of buildings.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Ottoman hammams were largely modeled on their Roman and Byzantine predecessors. They contained three main areas: a hot room, a moderate room and a cool room. Both men and women could attend hammams, but they bathed in separate areas.

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Â îñíîâíîì âèêèíãè ðàñøèðÿëè ãðàíèöû ñâîèõ âëàäåíèé îãíåì è ìå÷îì, íî òîðãîâëÿ çàíèìàëà â èõ æèçíè íå ïîñëåäíåå ìåñòî. TEXT.English: Although they did seek to extend their empire through piracy and invasion, for much of the time the Vikings were merchants, with a trading network that extended from Greenland, Iceland, and Finland into the British Isles, Western Europe, and the Mediterranean. Viking merchants are known to have traded Russian slaves at Constantinople for silks and spices, and they brought furs and ivory from far-away Greenland to ports throughout Europe, North Africa and the Middle East.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The earliest Viking trading posts were quite primitive settlements, consisting of simple dwellings and warehouses constructed of whatever local material was readily available. Over time many of the posts flourished, becoming important cities in their own rights. For example the Irish capitol of Dublin began its existence as a Viking trading post; and after being captured by the Vikings, the English city of York became a thriving trading center, second in importance only to London.

Çóëóñû áûëè õðàáðûìè è äèñöèïëèíèðîâàííûìè âîèòåëÿìè.
TEXT.English: Upon ascending to power, the great Zulu leader Shaka implemented a number of important civil and military reforms to his growing civilization. In addition to his important innovations to Zulu warfare - he is often credited with the invention of the famous Zulu "buffalo horns" formation, as well as the introduction of the "iklwa," a short stabbing spear that proved enormously successful in combat - Shaka also reorganized Zulu society to better support his military ambitions.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]At the age of six, young boys joined Shaka's military as apprentice warriors. (This is a surprising parallel to the way that Spartan boys were raised - though it's unlikely that Shaka every heard of the Spartans.) The young warriors were trained in "ikhanda" (special military camps). During their training the Zulu boys were imbued with military fervor, put through rigorous physical exercise, and of course instructed in the use of the Zulu's powerful weapons. In battle they carried supplies and extra weapons for the warriors, and it is believed that they occasionally went out on hit-and-run raids against less dangerous enemy tribes. When the boys reached the appropriate age, they became full-fledged warriors. As a result the Zulu warriors were among the bravest and best-trained soldiers in the world.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Although the earliest sailing ships were undoubtedly used for fishing and transportation, man quickly found ways to turn these vehicles into weapons. Typically, non-military vessels are no match for dedicated warships crewed with professional warriors. However, warships are expensive to build, crew and maintain, and only fairly wealthy - or bloodthirsty or desperate - nations possess large standing navies.

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Êîïüå ñàìî ïî ñåáå - íåïëîõîå îðóæèå, íî îòðÿä ïèêèíåðîâ ãîðàçäî ýôôåêòèâíåå, ÷åì ñîëäàò-îäèíî÷êà. Îïòèìàëüíûé áîåâîé ïîðÿäîê äëÿ ïèêèíåðîâ - ïëîòíûé ñòðîé, ïîçâîëÿþùèé ó÷àñòâîâàòü â áèòâå íå òîëüêî ïåðâîé, íî è ñëåäóþùèì çà íåé øåðåíãàì. Îäíàêî íåïîäãîòîâëåííûå ïèêèíåðû ìîãóò áûòü îïàñíû êàê äëÿ âðàãîâ, òàê è äëÿ ñâîåé êîãîðòû!
TEXT.English: [TAB]While the spear is a potent weapon in itself, it truly comes into power when employed in large numbers. Spears get their best effect when the warriors stand in tight formations, allowing those behind the front ranks to engage in combat as well. This however requires a good deal of training - else the soldiers are as dangerous to their cohorts as they are to the enemy.

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Íàèáîëåå ýôôåêòèâíî êîïüåíîñöû ñðàæàëèñü â ãðå÷åñêèõ ôàëàíãàõ - ïëîòíîì ñòðîå èç íåñêîëüêèõ øåðåíã. Âðàãà ìîãëè àòàêîâàòü îäíîâðåìåííî äî ïÿòè ðÿäîâ âîèíîâ. Ôàëàíãè ñîñòîÿëè òîëüêî èç îïûòíûõ è îòëè÷íî äèñöèïëèíèðîâàííûõ âîèíîâ. Ñ ðàçâèòèåì òàêòèêè è âîåííûõ òåõíîëîãèé ôàëàíãà åñòåñòâåííûì îáðàçîì óñòàðåëà, íî â ýïîõó àíòè÷íîñòè îíà áûëà ìîùíåéøåé áîåâîé åäèíèöåé.
TEXT.English: [TAB]Spearmen reached their height of potency under the Greeks, who deployed their men in "phalanxes," remarkably tight formations in which up to five ranks of soldiers were able to engage the enemy at one time. Phalanxes required an extraordinary amount of training and discipline. Eventually as military tactics and technology advanced they would be supplanted, but in their day they were the undisputed masters of the ancient battlefield.

TEXT.Russian: 800 ãîä í.ý. Âû Ðàãíàð Ëîäáðîê, êîðîëü âèêèíãîâ. Çèìà âûäàëàñü äîëãîé, íî ìîðîçíûé âîçäóõ íå ìåøàåò âàì ëþáîâàòüñÿ ñâîèìè ãðîçíûìè êîðàáëÿìè. Ýòè äðàêàðû ïîíåñóò âàñ ê íîâûì çåìëÿì ïî õîëîäíûì ìîðñêèì âîëíàì. [PARAGRAPH:1]Âàì íóæíû äåíüãè, ÷òîáû ïðîêîðìèòü ñâîþ ñåìüþ è íàðîä? Êîíå÷íî. [PARAGRAPH:1]Âàì íóæíî çàñëóæèòü ïîõâàëó Îäèíà? Âîçìîæíî. [PARAGRAPH:1]Âàì íóæíû ïðèêëþ÷åíèÿ? Ðàçóìååòñÿ! [PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Îïèñàíèå ñöåíàðèÿ:[\BOLD] èãðà äëèòñÿ 200 õîäîâ. Âàøà öåëü - íàêîïèòü %d1 åä. çîëîòà. Íàéäåííûå è äîñòàâëåííûå â ñòîëèöó ñîêðîâèùà ïîìîãóò âàì ïîïîëíèòü êàçíó.
TEXT.English: The Year is 800 AD and you are the Viking King, Ragnar Lodbrok. The chill of the long winter bites into your fingers as you look over your fleet of longships. These boats will take you across the cold sea to your raiding destination. Do you raid for the money to provide for your children and people? Surely. Do you raid to prove yourself before your god? Possibly. Do you raid for the adventure? Definitely![PARAGRAPH:1][BOLD]Game Notes:[\BOLD]The Scenario lasts 200 turns. Your goal is to accumulate %d1 gold before the end of the game. Researching treasure locations and then returning these treasures to your capital will increase your gold.

TEXT.English: As the wars between the various warring states wore on, many sought to end the constant struggle through peaceful means. Even some kings, more 'enlightened' than their warlike counterparts, wished to fight no more. One option was to have all remaining state leaders to meet together in an "Emperor's Council" and decide together who should rule all of China. Once built, the Emperor's Council will unlock the Diplomatic Victory option.

TEXT.English: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Temples[COLOR_REVERT] increase a city's happiness and culture. They are especially useful for expanding your civilization's borders during the early game.
[COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Prodromoi[COLOR_REVERT] are good scouting units. They are lightly armored and extremely fast.

TEXT.English: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Peltasts[COLOR_REVERT] are cheap units, useful for reinforcing tactical locations such as hills and forests.

TEXT.Russian: Âðåìÿ ïëàòèòü äàíü! Îòêàç îçíà÷àåò ÂÎÉÍÓ!

TEXT.Russian: [TAB]Ïàìÿòíèê - ñòðîåíèå, íàïîìèíàþùåå ëþäÿì î âàæíîì ñîáûòèè, êîòîðîå ïðîèçîøëî â èõ ñòðàíå, èëè î âåëèêîì ÷åëîâåêå. Èõ âîçâîäèëè èç ðàçëè÷íûõ ìàòåðèàëîâ - äåðåâà, êàìíÿ è äàæå äðàãîöåííûõ ìåòàëëîâ. Íà ñåãîäíÿøíèé äåíü èç äðåâíèõ ïàìÿòíèêîâ óöåëåëè òîëüêî êàìåííûå - îñòàëüíûå áûëè ðàçðóøåíû âðåìåíåì èëè ìàðîäåðàìè.
TEXT.English: [TAB]A monument is a structure that reminds people of an important event that occured in the area, or an important person - a famous general or leader, perhaps. Different cultures have constructed monuments out of varied materials - wood, stone, or even precious metals. Generally, the only ancient monuments remaining today are those made out of stone: over time the wooden monuments have decayed, and the ones constructed of precious metals have been looted and destroyed.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Ïàìÿòíèêè[COLOR_REVERT] ïîâûøàþò êóëüòóðíûé óðîâåíü è ïîìîãàþò ðàñøèðèòü ãðàíèöû ãîðîäà íà ðàííåì ýòàïå èãðû.
TEXT.English: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Monuments[COLOR_REVERT] provide a small amount of culture, and are a good way to expand city borders early on.

TEXT.English: The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Mongol Horse Archer[COLOR_REVERT] is an all-around unit which can defeat almost any army. Howeer, beware when facing entrenched units or anti-horse units like Spearmen.

TEXT.English: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Mounted Swordsmen[COLOR_REVERT] are designed to help fill the gaps left by Mongol Horse Archers. Use them to take out enemy Melee units like Spearmen or Swordsmen.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Àëòàðü äèíàñòèè[COLOR_REVERT] äàåò ïðèðîñò êóëüòóðû è ïîçâîëÿåò ñîçäàòü îäíîãî ñâÿùåííîñëóæèòåëÿ. Êðîìå òîãî, ñ ýòèì çäàíèåì âû ñìîæåòå ïðîèçâîäèòü [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]ýìèññàðîâ äèíàñòèè[COLOR_REVERT]. Ýòè þíèòû ïîìîãàþò óêðåïëÿòü "êðîâíûå óçû" è óñòàíàâëèâàòü äèïëîìàòè÷åñêèå ñâÿçè.
TEXT.English: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Family Altar[COLOR_REVERT] provides a small culture bonus and allows 1 Priest specialist, but their most important function is to allow the construction of [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Family Emissary[COLOR_REVERT] units, vital to spreading 'bloodlines' and forging diplomatic ties.

TEXT.English: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Temple[COLOR_REVERT] is a cultural building which provides a small bit of Happiness to the city it's built in.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Âåëèêàÿ áèáëèîòåêà[COLOR_REVERT] ïîçâîëÿåò áåñïëàòíî èçó÷èòü îäíó òåõíîëîãèþ.

TEXT.English: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Sun Tzu's Art of War[COLOR_REVERT] gives all units built on the same continent +1 Experience, good for those planning on military conquest.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Âåëèêàÿ ñòåíà[COLOR_REVERT] - ìàëîå ÷óäî ñâåòà, êîòîðîå óâåëè÷èâàåò íà 1 åäèíèöó ÷èñëåííîñòü íàñåëåíèÿ è çäîðîâüå â êàæäîì ãîðîäå, à òàêæå çàùèùàåò òåððèòîðèþ îò âòîðæåíèé âàðâàðîâ.
TEXT.English: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]National Wall[COLOR_REVERT] is a national wonder which gives every city a growth boost with +1 Population and +1 Health while also (and perhaps more importantly) preventing barbarians from crossing into your territory.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Ðîäîâàÿ ëåòîïèñü[COLOR_REVERT] - ìàëîå ÷óäî ñâåòà, ïîâûøàþùåå ðîæäàåìîñòü çíàìåíèòîñòåé.
TEXT.English: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Book of History[COLOR_REVERT] is a national wonder which gives the city it's built in increased Great Person generation.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Ïîäçåìíàÿ óñûïàëüíèöà[COLOR_REVERT] - ÷óäî ñâåòà, êîòîðîå óìåíüøàåò íåäîâîëüñòâî âîéíîé íà 75% è ïðåäîñòàâëÿåò áåñïëàòíîãî ñïåöèàëèñòà â êàæäîì ãîðîäå.
TEXT.English: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Underground Tomb[COLOR_REVERT] is a multi-faceted wonder, eliminating 75% of the War Weariness in your cities while also providing +1 free Specialists to all of your cities.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Èìïåðàòîðñêèé ñîâåò[COLOR_REVERT] - êëþ÷ ê äèïëîìàòè÷åñêîé ïîáåäå. Ñðàçó ïîñëå åãî ïîñòðîéêè ãîëîñîâàíèåì âûáèðàåòñÿ âåðõîâíûé ïðàâèòåëü, à ÷åðåç êîðîòêîå âðåìÿ - äèïëîìàòè÷åñêèé ïîáåäèòåëü.
TEXT.English: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Emperor's Council[COLOR_REVERT] is the key to the diplomatic victory. Once built a vote will be held for the leader of the Council and shortly afterwards a second for the game's diplomatic victor.
The default civic with no special attributes.

TEXT.Russian: Çà îäèí õîä ìîæíî ïðèçûâàòü äî 2 þíèòîâ; êàçàðìû ïîäíèìàþò íàñòðîåíèå íà 2 åä. Ýòà ïàðàäèãìà ïîçâîëÿåò áûñòðî ñôîðìèðîâàòü âîéñêî è ïîäíÿòü íàñòðîåíèå â ãîðîäàõ.
TEXT.English: Allows the drafting of up to 2 units per turn from each; Barracks provide +2 Happiness. Good for extra happiness or when trying to build up a military force quickly.

TEXT.Russian: Ïðîèçâîäñòâî âîåííûõ þíèòîâ óñêîðÿåòñÿ íà 50%; +1 ê íàñòðîåíèþ â ãîðîäå çà êàæäûé âîåííûé þíèò; +1 åä. çîëîòà ê ñîäåðæàíèþ âîåííûõ þíèòîâ. Ýòà ïàðàäèãìà ïîçâîëÿåò áûñòðî ñôîðìèðîâàòü êðóïíóþ àðìèþ, õîòÿ è äîðîãîé öåíîé.
TEXT.English: Military production 50% faster and units give +1 Happiness; Military units cost +1 gold to support. Allows for much larger armies, but can be rather expensive to maintain.

TEXT.Russian: +200% ê ïîÿâëåíèþ çíàìåíèòîñòåé â ãîðîäàõ, èñïîâåäóþùèõ ãîñóäàðñòâåííóþ ðåëèãèþ; +1 åä. çîëîòà ê ñîäåðæàíèþ âîåííûõ þíèòîâ. Íåïëîõî äëÿ òåõ, êòî ïðåäïî÷èòàåò ïîêîðÿòü ãîðîäà íå âîåííîé ñèëîé, à ýêîíîìè÷åñêèì è êóëüòóðíûì âëèÿíèåì.
TEXT.English: +200% Great Person generation in cities with State Religion; Military units cost +1 gold to support. Alternative for those who prefer domination through economics and culture rather than armies.

TEXT.Russian: +50% ê ïðîèçâîäñòâó è äîõîäó â ñòîëèöå. Óíèâåðñàëüíîå ïðåèìóùåñòâî, ïîëåçíî êàê â âîåííîå, òàê è â ìèðíîå âðåìÿ.
TEXT.English: Provides +50% Production and Commerce in capital city. A well-rounded bonus which can be used for peaceful or wartime purposes.

TEXT.Russian: +1 åä. çîëîòà ñ êàæäîé äåðåâíè è ãîðîäêà. Ïîçâîëÿåò êîïèòü äåíüãè äëÿ óñêîðåíèÿ ïðîèçâîäñòâà.
TEXT.English: +1 Gold from Village and Town improvements; Can spend gold to finish production. Designed to fuel an economy and make use of the extra money by turning it into production.

TEXT.Russian: +1 åä. ïèùè ñ êàæäîé ôåðìû; -33% ê ïðîèçâîäñòâó âîåííûõ þíèòîâ. Ïîçâîëÿåò óâåëè÷èòü íàñåëåíèå, íî çàìåäëÿåò ôîðìèðîâàíèå àðìèè.
TEXT.English: +1 Food from Farm improvements; -33% Military unit production. Allows for a huge population but at the cost of penalties when building up an army.

TEXT.Russian: +2 ñïåöèàëèñòà â êàæäîì ãîðîäå. Ýòà âûãîäíàÿ ïàðàäèãìà äîñòóïíà íà ïîçäíèõ ýòàïàõ èãðû.
TEXT.English: All cities +2 receive Specialists. A powerful late-game civic which gives a boost to every city's economy.

TEXT.Russian: +15% ê äîõîäó îò êàæäîãî ãîðîäà. Äåöåíòðàëèçàöèÿ äàåò îáùèé ýêîíîìè÷åñêèé ïîäúåì.
TEXT.English: +15% Commerce in all cities. A general economic upgrade from Decentralization.

TEXT.Russian: Íåò äîïîëíèòåëüíûõ ðàñõîäîâ íà ñîäåðæàíèå èç-çà óäàëåíèÿ îò ñòîëèöû. +1 ê ïðîèçâîäñòâó ïèùè íà ðóäíèêàõ, â ìàñòåðñêèõ, íà âåòðÿíûõ è âîäÿíûõ ìåëüíèöàõ.
TEXT.English: No Maintenance costs from distance to Capital. Mines, Workshops, Windmills and Watermills provide +1 Food. Good for large empires and those which rely on production-based plot improvements.

TEXT.Russian: +25% ê äîõîäó â ñòîëèöå; +100% ê êóëüòóðå âî âñåõ ãîðîäàõ. Ïðîñòåéøàÿ ðåëèãèîçíàÿ ïàðàäèãìà.
TEXT.English: +25% Commerce in Capital and +100% Culture in all cities. Basic religion upgrade available early on.

TEXT.Russian: +1 ê íàñòðîåíèþ â êàæäîì ãîðîäå îò ëåñíûõ êëåòîê. Ïðîñòîé ñïîñîá ïîäíÿòü íàñòðîåíèå æèòåëåé.
TEXT.English: All cities receive +1 Happiness from Forest plots. A good option for those suffering from Happiness problems.

TEXT.Russian: +2 åä. çäîðîâüÿ â êàæäîì ãîðîäå. Õîðîøåå ñðåäñòâî äëÿ óëó÷øåíèÿ ñàíèòàðíûõ óñëîâèé.
TEXT.English: All cities receive +2 Health. A way to curb Unhealthiness in cities.

TEXT.Russian: +33% ê íàóêå â êàæäîì ãîðîäå. Ñïîñîáñòâóåò ìîùíîìó ïðîðûâó â íàó÷íûõ äîñòèæåíèÿõ.
TEXT.English: All cities +33% Science. For those who make this civic a priority it can provide a massive boost to research.

TEXT.Russian: Âñå íîâûå þíèòû ïîëó÷àþò 4 äîïîëíèòåëüíûå åäèíèöû îïûòà. Âî âñåõ ãîðîäàõ íàñòðîåíèå ïàäàåò íà 1 åäèíèöó îò êàæäîé ïðåäñòàâëåííîé â ãîðîäå ðåëèãèè. Ïîçâîëÿåò ïîñòðîèòü ìîùíóþ àðìèþ çà ñ÷åò óõóäøåíèÿ ìîðàëüíîãî äóõà æèòåëåé.
TEXT.English: All new units built receive +4 Experience Points. All cities +1 Unhappiness for each religion present. Enduring the happiness penalty with this civic will allow for a much more experienced and powerful army.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Ýìèññàðû äèíàñòèè[COLOR_REVERT] ðàñïðîñòðàíÿþò êðîâíûå óçû. Ïðè ýòîì â âàøèõ ãîðîäàõ ïîäíèìàåòñÿ íàñòðîåíèå, à â ÷óæèõ - óëó÷øàåòñÿ îòíîøåíèå ê âàì.
TEXT.English: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Family Emissaries[COLOR_REVERT] are used to spread family bloodlines to cities, both your own for happiness as well as to those of others in order to gain a diplomatic advantage.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Êîëåñíèöà I[COLOR_REVERT] - ýòî êîííûé þíèò, ñïîñîáíûé íàíåñòè áûñòðûé è íåîæèäàííûé óäàð, íî óÿçâèìûé äëÿ [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]êîïåéùèêîâ[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.English: The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Chariot I[COLOR_REVERT] is an early Mounted unit, designed for fast shock attacks, but it is vulnerable to [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Polearm[COLOR_REVERT] units..

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Êîëåñíèöà II[COLOR_REVERT] - ýòî ìîäåðíèçèðîâàííûé êîííûé þíèò, ñïîñîáíûé íàíåñòè áûñòðûé è íåîæèäàííûé óäàð, íî âñå òàê æå óÿçâèìûé äëÿ [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]êîïåéùèêîâ[COLOR_REVERT]. Èìååò íåáîëüøîå ïðåèìóùåñòâî ïåðåä [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]òÿæåëîé êàâàëåðèåé I[COLOR_REVERT] òîé æå ýïîõè, íî ñòîèò äîðîæå è èìååò ìåíüøå øàíñîâ íà îòñòóïëåíèå.
TEXT.English: The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Chariot II[COLOR_REVERT] is an improved Mounted unit, designed for fast shock attacks, but remains vulnerable to [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Polearm[COLOR_REVERT] units. It has a slight power advantage over the contemporary [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Heavy Cavalry I[COLOR_REVERT], but costs more and has a smaller chance of retreating.

TEXT.Russian: Âñàäíèê [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]òÿæåëîé êàâàëåðèè I[COLOR_REVERT] - áûñòðûé è ìîùíûé þíèò, íî óÿçâèìûé äëÿ [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]êîïåéùèêîâ[COLOR_REVERT]. Ñòîèò íåìíîãî äåøåâëå, ÷åì [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]êîëåñíèöà II[COLOR_REVERT], íî è íåìíîãî ñëàáåå åå. Èìååò áîëüøå øàíñîâ íà îòñòóïëåíèå.
TEXT.English: The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Heavy Cavalry I[COLOR_REVERT] unit is a fast and powerful Mounted unit, but is vulnerable to [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Polearm[COLOR_REVERT] units. It costs slightly less than the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Chariot II[COLOR_REVERT] and has a higher chance to retreat from a losing battle, but is slightly weaker in combat.

Íåêîòîðûå ñîñåäè íå ïîæåëàþò âïóñêàòü âàñ íà ñâîþ òåððèòîðèþ, íî ïîìíèòå, ÷òî ó âàñ â çàïàñå åñòü òàêòè÷åñêàÿ õèòðîñòü: ñ ïîìîùüþ êðîâíûõ óç âû ìîæåòå ïîðîäíèòüñÿ ñ íåóñòóï÷èâîé äèíàñòèåé. [PARAGRAPH:2]Ïîáåäèòü ìîæíî ñ ïîìîùüþ äèïëîìàòèè, çàõâàòà ãîñóäàðñòâ è äîñòèæåíèÿ çàäàííîãî êîëè÷åñòâà î÷êîâ. Óñëîâèåì äèïëîìàòè÷åñêîé ïîáåäû ÿâëÿåòñÿ ñòðîèòåëüñòâî [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]èìïåðàòîðñêîãî ñîâåòà[COLOR_REVERT]. Ïîñëå åãî ïîñòðîéêè áóäåò ïðîâåäåíî äâà ãîëîñîâàíèÿ - âûáîðû ãëàâû ñîâåòà è âûáîðû èìïåðàòîðà Êèòàÿ. Ãëàâà ñîâåòà àâòîìàòè÷åñêè ïîïàäàåò â ÷èñëî êàíäèäàòîâ íà èìïåðàòîðñêèé òðîí. Ó êàæäîãî åñòü âîçìîæíîñòü áûòü âûáðàííûì èëè ïðîèãðàòü âûáîðû, ïîýòîìó ñòðîéòå îòíîøåíèÿ ñ ñîñåäÿìè îñìîòðèòåëüíî![NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Áèòâà[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïî ñðàâíåíèþ ñ áèòâàìè â èñõîäíîé èãðå, êîìàíäîâàíèå âîéñêàìè ìîæåò ïîêàçàòüñÿ âàì óñëîæíåííûì. Îñîáåííîñòü ïðåäñòàâëåííîé ýïîõè â òîì, ÷òî äëÿ äîñòèæåíèÿ ìàëûõ öåëåé ñîçäàâàëèñü îãðîìíûå àðìèè, à îñíîâíîé óïîð äåëàëñÿ íà îáîðîíó. Íî ìóäðûé ïîëêîâîäåö ñïðàâèòñÿ ñî ñâîåé çàäà÷åé â ëþáûõ óñëîâèÿõ![PARAGRAPH:2]Êàê è â îáû÷íîé èãðå, äëÿ âçÿòèÿ ãîðîäà íåîáõîäèìû [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]ìå÷íèêè[COLOR_REVERT], à äëÿ óñïåøíîé îñàäû íóæíî ðàçðóøèòü óêðåïëåíèÿ ïóòåì áîìáàðäèðîâêè. [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Êàòàïóëüòû[COLOR_REVERT] ñòàíîâÿòñÿ äîñòóïíû òîëüêî íà ïîçäíèõ ýòàïàõ èãðû, íî [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]ãàëåðû[COLOR_REVERT] ñïîñîáíû îáñòðåëèâàòü ïðèáðåæíûå ãîðîäà. Èñïîëüçóéòå èõ ñ óìîì, è ïîáåäà ó âàñ â êàðìàíå![PARAGRAPH:2]È ïîñëåäíåå: îïàñàéòåñü íàïàäåíèÿ âàðâàðîâ, íàäåæíî çàùèùàéòå ãðàíèöû!
TEXT.English: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Diplomacy:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]In this scenario, diplomacy is the key to success - whether you're leading a group of Civs into victory or are the target of everyone else is determined by your relations with the states you share the map with. Everyone is out to win control of China, and getting your neighbors to work with you rather than eye you suspiciously will be difficult. But you have a powerful tool: your [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Family Bloodline[COLOR_REVERT].[PARAGRAPH:2]Your Family Bloodline (that is, your Religion) is your way of manipulating neighboring states into becoming your friends and allies. Acquiring Open Borders and then sending your [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Family Emissaries[COLOR_REVERT] (Missionaries) is an important way of spreading your influence. But sometimes other Civs won't even be willing to grant you access to their territory. While troublesome, there remains a tactic available: you may change your OWN State Bloodline to match THEIRS. This will provide an immediate boost in relations which will give you an opening to more fruitful cooperation in the future. This may even be done many times to befriend multiple Civs, but beware the impact of this maneuver on your current allies![PARAGRAPH:2]Victory is possible through Diplomacy, as well as by Conquest and (if the time limit is reached) by Score. Winning in this way requires constructing the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Emperor's Council[COLOR_REVERT] World Wonder. Once built, two votes will be held, one to determine the Council Leader and then for who should become the Emperor of China. The Council Leader will always be one of the two possible candidates for becoming Emperor. It is possible for no one to be elected or even to lose, so manage the relations with your friends and foes carefully![NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Battle:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Compared with warfare in a normal game of Civilization 4, combat in this scenario may seem to be quite a bit more difficult to handle. This was an era of history very much focused on defense and the use of massive armies to achieve small gains. But there are ways to avoid losing scores of men over minor objectives.[PARAGRAPH:2]As with a normal game, [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Swordsmen[COLOR_REVERT] are important for killing City defenders. Bombardment of enemy strongholds to wear down their defenses is vital for capturing them. [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Catapults[COLOR_REVERT] are not available until somewhat late in the game, but the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Galley[COLOR_REVERT] Naval Unit is able to Bombard cities from the many navigable rivers which flow through China. Use them wisely and you will be rewarded.[PARAGRAPH:2]One final warning: If on the periphery of civilization, beware Barbarian attacks!

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Ãåíåðàëû[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Âîåííûå ëèäåðû ðîæäàþòñÿ ïî ìåðå íàêîïëåíèÿ âàøåé äåðæàâîé áîåâîãî îïûòà. Êîãäà âû âûèãðàåòå íåñêîëüêî áèòâ, â ñòîëèöå ïîÿâèòñÿ ïåðâûé [LINK=UNIT_GREAT_GENERAL]ãåíåðàë[\LINK]. Äëÿ ñëåäóþùåãî ãåíåðàëà ïîíàäîáèòñÿ â äâà ðàçà áîëüøå îïûòà, è òàê äàëåå.[PARAGRAPH:2]Åñëè ãåíåðàëà ïðèêðåïèòü ê äðóãîìó âîåííîìó þíèòó, îí ñòàíåò âîåíà÷àëüíèêîì. Ïðè ýòîì þíèòû, íàõîäÿùèåñÿ íà òîé æå êëåòêå, åäèíîâðåìåííî ïîëó÷àò íåêîòîðîå êîëè÷åñòâî îïûòà. Þíèò, ê êîòîðîìó ïðèêðåïëåí âîåíà÷àëüíèê, ìîäåðíèçèðóåòñÿ áåñïëàòíî. Îí ñîõðàíÿåò âåñü ñâîé îïûò è ïîëó÷àåò äîñòóï ê îñîáûì êâàëèôèêàöèÿì: [LINK=PROMOTION_COMBAT6]Áîé VI[\LINK], [LINK=PROMOTION_MEDIC3]Ìåäèê III[\LINK], [LINK=PROMOTION_TACTICS]Òàêòèêà[\LINK], [LINK=PROMOTION_LEADERSHIP]Ëèäåðñòâî[\LINK] è [LINK=PROMOTION_MORALE]Áîåâîé äóõ[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2]Äðóãîé âàðèàíò ïðèìåíåíèÿ ãåíåðàëà - ñòðîèòåëüñòâî â ãîðîäå [LINK=BUILDING_MILITARY_ACADEMY]âîåííîé àêàäåìèè[\LINK], óñêîðÿþùåé ïðîèçâîäñòâî âîåííûõ þíèòîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2]Òàêæå ãåíåðàë ìîæåò ñòàòü [LINK=SPECIALIST_GREAT_GENERAL]âîåííûì íàñòàâíèêîì[\LINK] ãîðîäà. Òîãäà âîåííûå þíèòû, ïðîèçâîäèìûå â ýòîì ãîðîäå, áóäóò ïîëó÷àòü äîïîëíèòåëüíûé îïûò.
TEXT.English: [H1]Great Generals[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Great Generals are military leaders that emerge as your civilization gains combat experience. When you have won enough battles to reach a certain threshold of total experience, a [LINK=UNIT_GREAT_GENERAL]Great General[\LINK] appears in your capital city. Each Great General requires twice the amount of combat experience that was needed to generate the one before.[PARAGRAPH:2]Once generated, you can turn your Great General into a Warlord by joining him with another unit in the field. That action also distributes a one-time experience bonus to units in the same tile. The unit receiving the Warlord can be upgraded at no cost, and retains all of its experience when doing so. The unit also gains access to some special promotions not normally available, such as [LINK=PROMOTION_COMBAT6]Combat VI[\LINK], [LINK=PROMOTION_MEDIC3]Medic III[\LINK], [LINK=PROMOTION_TACTICS]Tactics[\LINK], [LINK=PROMOTION_LEADERSHIP]Leadership[\LINK], and [LINK=PROMOTION_MORALE]Morale[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2]Alternatively, you can use your Great General to construct a [LINK=BUILDING_MILITARY_ACADEMY]military academy[\LINK] in a city. That city receives a production bonus when building military units.[PARAGRAPH:2]Finally, a Great General can join a city as a [LINK=SPECIALIST_GREAT_GENERAL]Great Military Instructor[\LINK]. New units constructed in that city immediately receive bonus experience points.

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Âàññàëüíûå ãîñóäàðñòâà[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ãîñóäàðñòâî ñ÷èòàåòñÿ âàññàëüíûì, åñëè îíî ïîä÷èíÿåòñÿ äðóãîìó ãîñóäàðñòâó (ñþçåðåíó) è ïëàòèò åìó äàíü â îáìåí íà ôèíàíñîâóþ è âîåííóþ ïîääåðæêó. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Ïðåèìóùåñòâà è íåäîñòàòêè âàññàëèòåòà[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïðè çàêëþ÷åíèè ñîãëàøåíèÿ î âàññàëèòåòå â äåðæàâå ñþçåðåíà [LINK=CONCEPT_HAPPINESS]íàñòðîåíèå[\LINK] ïîäíèìàåòñÿ, à â âàññàëüíîì ãîñóäàðñòâå - ñíèæàåòñÿ. [PARAGRAPH:2]Þíèòû ñþçåðåíà ìîãóò ñâîáîäíî ïåðåäâèãàòüñÿ ïî òåððèòîðèè âàññàëà, èíôîðìàöèÿ î ãîðîäàõ âàññàëà îòêðûòà äëÿ ñþçåðåíà. Íà òåððèòîðèè âàññàëà þíèòû ñþçåðåíà ïîëó÷àþò âñå ïðåèìóùåñòâà îò óêðåïëåíèé è âîññòàíàâëèâàþòñÿ òàê æå áûñòðî, êàê íà ðîäíîé çåìëå.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ñþçåðåí âïðàâå ïîòðåáîâàòü îò âàññàëà ëþáîé [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]ðåñóðñ[\LINK], äàæå åñëè ýòîò ðåñóðñ - åäèíñòâåííûé. Îòêàç ïëàòèòü äàíü âåäåò ê [LINK=CONCEPT_WAR]âîéíå[\LINK], ýòî åäèíñòâåííàÿ âîçìîæíîñòü íà÷àòü âîéíó ìåæäó ñþçåðåíîì è âàññàëîì. Âî âñåõ îñòàëüíûõ ñëó÷àÿõ ìåæäó íèìè ñîõðàíÿåòñÿ ìèð, è åñëè ñþçåðåí èäåò âîéíîé íà òðåòüå ãîñóäàðñòâî, âàññàë àâòîìàòè÷åñêè âñòóïàåò â âîéíó íà ñòîðîíå ñþçåðåíà. Âàññàëüíîå ãîñóäàðñòâî íå èìååò ïðàâà çàêëþ÷àòü ìèð èëè îáúÿâëÿòü âîéíó ñàìîñòîÿòåëüíî. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Çàòðàòû íà ñîäåðæàíèå[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ñòîèìîñòü [LINK=CONCEPT_MAINTENANCE]ñîäåðæàíèÿ[\LINK] ãîðîäîâ ñþçåðåíà âîçðàñòàåò ïðîïîðöèîíàëüíî êîëè÷åñòâó ãîðîäîâ âàññàëüíûõ ãîñóäàðñòâ. Îáðàòèòå âíèìàíèå: ñþçåðåí íå ñîäåðæèò âàññàëüíûå ãîðîäà. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Âèäû âàññàëüíûõ ñîãëàøåíèé[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Â ìèðíîå âðåìÿ äåðæàâà ìîæåò ïðåäëîæèòü ñâîé âàññàëèòåò áîëåå ñèëüíîìó ãîñóäàðñòâó ñ èçó÷åííîé ïàðàäèãìîé [LINK=TECH_FEUDALISM]ôåîäàëèçìà[\LINK]. Ýòî âðåìåííîå ñîãëàøåíèå, êîòîðîå ìîæåò áûòü ðàñòîðãíóòî âàññàëîì (íî íå ñþçåðåíîì) ïî èñòå÷åíèè 10 õîäîâ. Åñëè âî âðåìÿ äåéñòâèÿ ñîãëàøåíèÿ ëþáàÿ èç ñòîðîí âñòóïàåò â âîéíó ñ òðåòüèì ãîñóäàðñòâîì, ýòî ãîñóäàðñòâî ñòàíîâèòñÿ âðàãîì è ñþçåðåíà, è âàññàëà.[PARAGRAPH:2]Çàêëþ÷åíèå âàññàëüíîãî äîãîâîðà ñ âðàæäåáíîé äåðæàâîé ïðèâîäèò ê êàïèòóëÿöèè âàññàëà. Îòëè÷èå îò ìèðíîãî ñîãëàøåíèÿ â òîì, ÷òî ïîñëå [BOLD]êàïèòóëÿöèè[\BOLD] âàññàë íå ìîæåò ïðîâîçãëàñèòü íåçàâèñèìîñòü äàæå ïî èñòå÷åíèè 10 õîäîâ. Îäíàêî åñëè ïëîùàäü è íàñåëåíèå âàññàëüíîãî ãîñóäàðñòâà ñîñòàâëÿþò áîëåå ïîëîâèíû ïëîùàäè è íàñåëåíèÿ ñþçåðåíà, âàññàëèòåò àííóëèðóåòñÿ. Òàêæå âàññàëüíîå ãîñóäàðñòâî îáúÿâèòü î ñâîåé íåçàâèñèìîñòè, åñëè ñ ìîìåíòà êàïèòóëÿöèè îíî ïîòåðÿëî áîëåå ïîëîâèíû ñâîèõ çåìåëü. Â âîéíå ñ òðåòüèì ãîñóäàðñòâîì âàññàë âûñòóïàåò íà ñòîðîíå ñþçåðåíà.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Óñëîâèÿ ïîáåäû[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ïðè ïîäñ÷åòå î÷êîâ, â òîì ÷èñëå äëÿ [LINK=CONCEPT_VICTORY] óñëîâèé ïîáåäû[\LINK], ñ÷åò ñ ïîëîâèíû òåððèòîðèè è íàñåëåíèÿ âàññàëà èäåò â ïîëüçó ñþçåðåíà, äðóãàÿ ïîëîâèíà - â ïîëüçó âàññàëà. Òåì íå ìåíåå, ðîñò ÷èñëà âàññàëüíûõ ãîñóäàðñòâ âðÿä ëè ìîæíî ñ÷èòàòü óñïåøíîé ñòðàòåãèåé, ïîñêîëüêó ÷åì áîëüøå ó ñþçåðåíà âàññàëîâ, òåì áîëüøå îí ïëàòèò çà [LINK=CONCEPT_MAINTENANCE]ñîäåðæàíèå[\LINK] ãîðîäîâ, ÷òî íå ìîæåò íå ñêàçàòüñÿ íà ýêîíîìèêå ãîñóäàðñòâà.
TEXT.English: [H1]Vassal States[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]A vassal state is one that has sworn allegiance to another state, providing its master state with some benefits in exchange for the master's pledge to protect and promote the vassal's welfare. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Benefits of Vassal Agreements[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]A vassal agreement results in some extra [LINK=CONCEPT_HAPPINESS]happiness[\LINK] throughout the master's empire, as well as some unhappiness for the vassal.[PARAGRAPH:2]Other benefits for the master include a right of passage through vassal territory, and visibility inside all vassal cities. In addition, the master's units heal as fast as they heal in his own territory, and can take full advantage of the vassal's fortifications.[PARAGRAPH:2]The master has the right to demand access to any [LINK=CONCEPT_RESOURCES]resource[\LINK] under vassal control, even if it is their only one. However, there is one catch. If the vassal refuses to pay this tribute, the agreement immediately ends and a state of [LINK=CONCEPT_WAR]war[\LINK] automatically results between the two parties. That is the only case where a state of war can result between a master state and a vassal state. Normally, the two parties are prevented from attacking each other and in addition if the master goes to war against a third party, the vassal automatically enters the war on the side of the master. Vassal states do not have the power to declare war or make peace on their own.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Cost of Vassal Agreements[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]When possessing vassals, the Master civilization incurs a higher [LINK=CONCEPT_MAINTENANCE]maintenance[\LINK] cost for its own cities. This costs increases as the number of vassal cities under his control increases. (Note that the master doesn't pay maintenance for the vassal's cities - he just pays extra maintenance for his civ's cities.)[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Types of Vassal Agreements[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]During peace time, a civilization can offer to become a vassal of a more powerful civilization with knowledge of [LINK=TECH_FEUDALISM]Feudalism[\LINK]. This is a temporary agreement that can be broken by the vassal (but not by the master) after 10 turns. For this type of peaceful vassalage, when the agreement is signed, any civilization at war with either of the two parties at is automatically at war with both parties.[PARAGRAPH:2]During wartime, a vassal agreement results in capitulation. [BOLD]Capitulation[\BOLD] has the same effects as peaceful vassalage, but it cannot be broken by the vassal state even after 10 turns, unless the vassal state grows to more than half of the land area and population of the master state. Capitulation may also be annulled by the vassal if the vassal state loses half of its land area since the time the agreement was signed. Capitulation forces the vassal state to immediately adopt the master's war/peace state against third parties.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Victory Conditions[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]In terms of [LINK=CONCEPT_VICTORY]victory conditions[\LINK] and score, the master state gets credit for half of the land and population of the vassal state and the vassal state gets credit for the other half. (Note, however, that acquiring vassals is not a necessarily a ticket to an easy domination victory, because the higher [LINK=CONCEPT_MAINTENANCE]maintenance[\LINK] cost for your own cities [see above] may drag your economy to a halt.)

TEXT.Russian: [H1]Îðîøåíèå[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Äëÿ ïðîèçâîäñòâà [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]ïèùè[\LINK] [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_FARM]ôåðìàì[\LINK] íåîáõîäèìî îðîøåíèå îò ïðåñíîãî âîäîåìà: ðåêè, îçåðà èëè îàçèñà.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ñ èçó÷åíèåì [LINK=TECH_CIVIL_SERVICE]ãðàæäàíñêîé ñëóæáû[\LINK] ôåðìû, èìåþùèå äîñòóï ê âîäå, íà÷èíàþò "ðàñïðîñòðàíÿòü îðîøåíèå", òî åñòü ñàìè ñòàíîâÿòñÿ èñòî÷íèêîì âîäû. Îáúåäèíÿÿ ôåðìû â ñåòü, ìîæíî ðàñïàõèâàòü çåìëè, óäàëåííûå îò âîäîåìà.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ñ èçîáðåòåíèåì [LINK=TECH_BIOLOGY]áèîëîãèè[\LINK] íåîáõîäèìîñòü â îðîøåíèè îòïàäàåò.
TEXT.English: [H1]Irrigation[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=IMPROVEMENT_FARM]Farms[\LINK] require irrigation in order to provide their full [LINK=CONCEPT_FOOD]food[\LINK] benefits. Irrigation can be achieved by building the farm adjacent to a source of fresh water, like a river, lake, or oasis.[PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=TECH_CIVIL_SERVICE]Civil Service[\LINK] enables irrigated farms to become a source of irrigation themselves. That allows you to bring irrigation to distant locations by building a chain of farms from the source of fresh water.[PARAGRAPH:2]With the advent of [LINK=TECH_BIOLOGY]Biology[\LINK], Farms no longer require irrigation.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Scoring:[\BOLD][NEWLINE]Points in this scenario are earned through controlling Victory Resources. For every Victory Resource you control, you will earn 10 points per turn. When the game begins, each opposing Civilization controls a single Victory Resource, while your Civilization controls none. In order to win, you must capture at least 2 Victory Resources before your opponent's score gets too far ahead of your score. Good Luck!

Çà÷àñòóþ ãåðîè äîáèâàþòñÿ íåâîçìîæíîãî; èõ æèçíü, êàê ïðàâèëî, êîðîòêà è ñóðîâà, à âñå èõ ïîìûñëû - î ÷åñòè è ñëàâå, äîáûâàåìîé ðàòíûìè ïîäâèãàìè. Çà áåñ÷åñòüå æå ïðèõîäèòñÿ ïëàòèòü êðîâüþ èëè ñåðåáðîì. Âàæíóþ ðîëü â ñàãàõ èãðàþò ñâåðõúåñòåñòâåííûå ñèëû è ñêàíäèíàâñêèå áîãè.[PARAGRAPH:2]"Êîðîëåâñêèå ñàãè" ðàññêàçûâàþò î æèçíè ñêàíäèíàâñêèõ ïðàâèòåëåé. Îíè áûëè çàïèñàíû â ïåðèîä ñ XII ïî XIV ââ., ïîñëå îáðàùåíèÿ âèêèíãîâ â õðèñòèàíñòâî. Êàê íàèáîëåå òî÷íûå äîêóìåíòàëüíûå ñâåäåíèÿ î äîõðèñòèàíñêîé ýïîõå Ñêàíäèíàâèè, îíè èìåþò íåîñïîðèìóþ öåííîñòü äëÿ èñòîðèêîâ.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ñàãà - ýòî íå åäèíñòâåííûé ïðèìåð ýïè÷åñêîãî òâîð÷åñòâà â èñòîðèè ÷åëîâå÷åñòâà. Â äðóãèõ êóëüòóðàõ âñòðå÷àëèñü ïîäîáíûå ïî ôîðìå è íàñòðîåíèþ ïðîèçâåäåíèÿ - òàêîâû, íàïðèìåð, ýïîñû Ãîìåðà, ÿïîíñêèå ëåãåíäû î ñàìóðàÿõ, çàïàäíîàìåðèêàíñêèå ðàññêàçû î êîâáîÿõ. [PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.English: The Norse sagas are stories about Scandinavian history and folklore. The oldest were preserved for ages through an oral tradition before finally being written down towards the end of the medieval period. Sometimes the tales are realistic; sometimes they are clearly legendary and fantastic. Sagas served as both the formal history of the Viking kings and also the mythical stories of famous heroes. The world of the sagas is strongly pagan. Fate - a dominant concept in the pre-Christian Norse religion - often plays a central role in these tales. [PARAGRAPH:2]Sagas are epic tales in prose, often with stanzas or whole poems in alliterative verse embedded within them. The style tends to be impersonal, providing only terse details with no explanation of "why" - things simply happen, and no one questions Fate. Characters are only briefly introduced, with a few simple adjectives serving to show their personality ("brave warrior", "powerful king", etc.) Relationships between characters are complex. Heroes often have to overcome seemingly impossible tasks; life is generally short and cruel; and the only thing worth pursuing is honor and glory, gained through feats of arms. Any slight or insult to someone's honor has to be avenged, in blood or money. Often the world of the supernatural played a role in the sagas, and figures from the Norse religion could figure prominently. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Kings' Sagas are a group of specific Norse sagas that describe the lives of Scandinavian kings. They were written down between the twelfth and fourteenth centuries after the Vikings had converted to Christianity. These writings are the closest thing that exists to a history of the Scandinavians during the pre-Christian Viking Age, and they have been of inestimable value to historians who study the period. [PARAGRAPH:2]The saga is not strictly a Norse literary technique, and other cultures have produced works similar in form and tone. The epics of Homer, the samurai legends of Japan, and even the cowboy tales of the American West are examples of such works. [PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.English: This is a superior version of the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Spearman[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.Russian: Ýòîò ìîùíûé áîåâîé þíèò ýôôåêòèâåí ïðîòèâ êàâàëåðèè è ïðè çàùèòå õîëìîâ. Îí ïðåâîñõîäèò ïî áîåâûì õàðàêòåðèñòèêàì [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]êîïüåíîñöà[COLOR_REVERT] è [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]ãîïëèòà[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.English: This powerful melee combat unit gets a bonus against mounted units and is adept at hill defense. It is superior to the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Spearman[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Hoplite[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Òðèåðà[COLOR_REVERT] íå ìîæåò ïåðåâîçèòü âîåííûå þíèòû, íî áîëåå áûñòðîõîäíà è ñèëüíà, ÷åì [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]ãàëåðà[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.English: The [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Trireme[COLOR_REVERT] cannot carry military units, but it is faster and more powerful than the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Galley[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Øêîëà Ïëàòîíà[COLOR_REVERT] çíà÷èòåëüíî ïîâûøàåò íàó÷íûé è êóëüòóðíûé ïîòåíöèàë ãîðîäà.
TEXT.English: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Plato's Academy[COLOR_REVERT] greatly increase a city's scientific research as well as its cultural output.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Âûñîêèå ñòåíû[COLOR_REVERT] çàùèùàþò ãîðîä, íî íå ÿâëÿþòñÿ ïðåãðàäîé äëÿ àðòèëëåðèè. Ñòðîéòå èõ â ïîãðàíè÷íûõ ãîðîäàõ.
TEXT.English: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]High Walls[COLOR_REVERT] increase your city's defenses aganst pre-gunpowder units. Build them in cities near enemy civilizations.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Âîåííûé ëàãåðü[COLOR_REVERT] äàåò äîïîëíèòåëüíûé îïûò âñåì âîéñêàì, ïðîèçâåäåííûì â ãîðîäå. Ñòðîéòå âîåííûå ëàãåðÿ âî âñåõ ãîðîäàõ, ãäå ñîçäàþòñÿ âîåííûå þíèòû.
TEXT.English: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Military Encampment[COLOR_REVERT] grants additional experience points to troops built in their cities. Build them in all cities that will produce military units.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Àãîðû[COLOR_REVERT] çàìåíÿþò äðåâíèì ãðåêàì [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]ðûíêè[COLOR_REVERT]. Îíè ïîïîëíÿþò êàçíó ãîðîäà.
TEXT.English: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Agoras[COLOR_REVERT] are ancient Greek [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Markets[COLOR_REVERT]. They increase a city's wealth.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Òåàòð Äèîíèñà[COLOR_REVERT] ïîâûøàåò êóëüòóðíûé óðîâåíü, ïîçâîëÿåò ïðåâðàòèòü òðîèõ ãîðîæàí â àðòèñòîâ è óâåëè÷èâàåò øàíñ ïîÿâëåíèÿ [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]âåëèêîãî òàëàíòà[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.English: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Theatre of Dionysus[COLOR_REVERT] increases a city's cultural output. It allows you to turn 3 citizens into Artists, and it increases the city's chances of generating a [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Great Artist[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Îäåîí[COLOR_REVERT] ïîâûøàåò êóëüòóðíûé óðîâåíü è íàñòðîåíèå æèòåëåé, à òàêæå ïîçâîëÿåò ïðåâðàòèòü äâóõ ãîðîæàí â àðòèñòîâ.
TEXT.English: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Odeon[COLOR_REVERT] increases a city's cultural output and its happiness. It allows you to turn 2 citizens into Artists.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Õðàìû[COLOR_REVERT] ïîäíèìàþò íàñòðîåíèå è êóëüòóðíûé óðîâåíü ãîðîæàí. Îíè ïîëåçíû äëÿ ðàñøèðåíèÿ ãðàíèö äåðæàâû íà ðàííåì ýòàïå èãðû.
TEXT.English: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Temples[COLOR_REVERT] increase a city's happiness and culture. They are especially useful for expanding your civilization's borders during the early game.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Ìîíàñòûðè[COLOR_REVERT] ïîçâîëÿþò ïðîèçâîäèòü [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]ìèññèîíåðîâ[COLOR_REVERT]. Ýòè þíèòû ìîãóò ðàñïðîñòðàíÿòü âàøó âåðó â ñîñåäíèõ ãîðîäàõ. Êðîìå òîãî, ìîíàñòûðè äàþò äîïîëíèòåëüíûé ïðèðîñò êóëüòóðû è èññëåäîâàíèé.
TEXT.English: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Monasteries[COLOR_REVERT] allow you to create [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Missionaries[COLOR_REVERT], who can spread the faith in other cities. They also provide culture and a slight boost to research.

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Ýëëèíñêèé ñîáîð[COLOR_REVERT] çíà÷èòåëüíî ïîâûøàåò êóëüòóðíûé óðîâåíü è íàñòðîåíèå æèòåëåé, åñëè [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]ýëëèíèçì[COLOR_REVERT] ÿâëÿåòñÿ ãîñóäàðñòâåííîé ðåëèãèåé.
TEXT.English: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Hellenic Cathedral[COLOR_REVERT] greatly increases a city's cultural output. It makes a city's citizens happy (if [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Hellenism[COLOR_REVERT] is the state religion).

TEXT.Russian: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Çäàíèå ñåíàòà[COLOR_REVERT] óìåíüøàåò ðàñõîäû íà ñîäåðæàíèå è òðåáóåòñÿ äëÿ ïîñòðîéêè [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Çàïðåòíîãî ãîðîäà[COLOR_REVERT]. Ñåíàò ïîìîãàåò êîíòðîëèðîâàòü çàòðàòû íà ñîäåðæàíèå îáøèðíîé èìïåðèè.
TEXT.English: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Senate Buildings[COLOR_REVERT] lower city maintenance costs and are required to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Forbidden Palace[COLOR_REVERT] national wonder. They help manage the cost of controlling large empires.
To win you must destroy Civilization.

TEXT.Russian: Âàøà öåëü - óíè÷òîæåíèå âðàæåñêèõ äåðæàâ. Ïðîòèâíèêè ðàçâèâàþòñÿ áåç âàøåãî ó÷àñòèÿ óêàçàííîå ÷èñëî õîäîâ, ïîñëå ÷åãî íà ýêðàíå ïîÿâëÿåòñÿ ìåíþ îðäû. Âî âðåìÿ èãðû åãî ìîæíî âûçâàòü íàæàòèåì êëàâèøè F4. Ýòî ìåíþ ïîçâîëÿåò íàáèðàòü þíèòîâ è ïðèñâàèâàòü èì íîâûå êâàëèôèêàöèè. Áèòâû è ãðàáåæè ïðèíåñóò âàì çîëîòî äëÿ óêðåïëåíèÿ àðìèè. Äëÿ ïîáåäû íóæíî çàõâàòèòü âñå äåðæàâû.
TEXT.English: The objective of this scenario is to destroy Civilization. You will select the number of turns you wish to allow the game to autoplay. After the autoplay finishes, you will be taken to the Barbarian Horde screen. Use the Barbarian Horde Screen (F4) to purchase units and promotions. As you pillage, fight, and conquer civilization you will gain treasure which you can use to buy more units and promotions. You win once you have conquered all of the civilizations.

Æèòåëè äðåâíèõ Àôèí ïîïîëíèëè ìèðîâóþ ñîêðîâèùíèöó êóëüòóðû, íàóêè è ïîëèòèêè, ñòàëè ïåðâîîòêðûâàòåëÿìè ôèëîñîôèè è äðàìû, íàóêè è äåìîêðàòèè. Íî ïåðñèäñêèå âîéíû ðàññòàâèëè âñå íà ñâîè ìåñòà. Â Ìàðàôîíñêîé áèòâå â 492 ã. äî í.ý. àôèíñêèå ãîïëèòû ðàçáèëè ïðåâîñõîäÿùèå ñèëû ïðîòèâíèêà, íî êîãäà äåñÿòü ëåò ñïóñòÿ ïåðñû âåðíóëèñü ñ ãîðàçäî áîëüøåé àðìèåé, îáúåäèíåííîå ãðå÷åñêîå âîéñêî íå ñìîãëî âûñòîÿòü. [PARAGRAPH:1]Íåñìîòðÿ íà ãîðå÷ü ïîðàæåíèÿ, àôèíñêèé ôëîò óäåðæèâàë ñâîè ïîçèöèè è ðàçáèë ïåðñîâ â áèòâå ïðè Ñàëàìèñå â 480 ã. äî í.ý. Ñîâìåñòíûìè óñèëèÿìè ãðåêè ïîñòåïåííî îòâîåâûâàëè ñâîè çåìëè, è â êîíöå êîíöîâ ïîä íà÷àëîì Àôèí áûëà ñîçäàíà Äåëîññêàÿ ëèãà, âêëþ÷àâøàÿ â ñåáÿ íàèáîëåå êðóïíûå ïðèáðåæíûå ïîñåëåíèÿ è îñòðîâíûå ãîðîäà-ãîñóäàðñòâà ãðåêîâ. Ñèëàìè Ëèãè ïåðñû áûëè îòáðîøåíû, è íåñêîëüêî âàæíûõ ïîñåëåíèé íà ïîáåðåæüå Ìàëîé Àçèè è áëèçëåæàùèõ îñòðîâàõ áûëè âîçâðàùåíû Ãðåöèè. Ïî îêîí÷àíèè âîéíû àôèíÿíå âåðíóëèñü äîìîé è çà íåñêîëüêî ëåò îòñòðîèëè åùå áîëåå ñèëüíûé è âåëè÷åñòâåííûé ãîðîä, ÷åì ïðåæäå. [PARAGRAPH:1]Àôèíû ñòàëè ãëàâíûì ãîðîäîì-ãîñóäàðñòâîì Ãðåöèè. Ðàçâèòûé ôëîò îáåñïå÷èâàë îáøèðíûå òîðãîâûå ñâÿçè, è Äåëîññêàÿ ëèãà ñî âðåìåíåì ïðåâðàòèëàñü èç âîåííîãî ñîþçà â òîðãîâóþ èìïåðèþ, ñ êîòîðîé Àôèíû ïîëó÷àëè ñòàáèëüíûé äîõîä. Ýòî áåñïîêîèëî ïðàâèòåëåé ãîðîäîâ, íå âõîäèâøèõ â Ëèãó, è â ïðîòèâîâåñ ðàñòóùåé àôèíñêîé ìîùè îíè ðåøèëè ñîçäàòü Ñïàðòàíñêèé ñîþç.[PARAGRAPH:1]Â 431 ãîäó äî í.ý. ìåæäó Äåëîññêîé ëèãîé è Ñïàðòàíñêèì ñîþçîì ðàçâÿçàëàñü âîéíà. Ïîä êîìàíäîâàíèåì Ïåðèêëà, âåëè÷àéøåãî àôèíñêîãî ïîëêîâîäöà è ïîëèòèêà, Àôèíû îäåðæàëè ìíîæåñòâî ïîáåä, íî òàê è íå âûíóäèëè ñïàðòàíöåâ ñäàòüñÿ. Ïîñëå ãèáåëè Ïåðèêëà îò ÷óìû, ïîäîðâàâøåé ñèëû àôèíÿí, êîìàíäîâàíèå ïåðåøëî ê ìåíåå îïûòíûì ïîëêîâîäöàì. Êðîâîïðîëèòíàÿ è áåññìûñëåííàÿ âîéíà ðàñòÿíóëàñü íà 30 ëåò. [PARAGRAPH:1]Òàê íàçûâàåìûå "äëèííûå ñòåíû" íàäåæíî çàùèùàëè Àôèíû îò âòîðæåíèÿ âðàãà. Ãîðîä ïîëó÷àë ïðèïàñû èç îòäàëåííûõ óãîëêîâ ñâîåé èìïåðèè, íåäîñòóïíûõ äëÿ ïðîòèâíèêà. Ýòî ïîçâîëÿëî Àôèíàì ïðîäîëæàòü âîéíó áåç òÿæåëûõ ïîñëåäñòâèé, õîòÿ çà äîëãèé ñðîê äåìîêðàòè÷åñêèå îñíîâû ïðàâëåíèÿ ïîøàòíóëèñü. Âîçìîæíî, àôèíÿíàì óäàëîñü áû çàêëþ÷èòü ìèð ñî ñâîèìè âðàãàìè, íî îíè ïðèíÿëè îïðîìåò÷èâîå ðåøåíèå çàõâàòèòü Ñèöèëèþ è îòïðàâèëè êðóïíóþ àðìèþ íà îñòðîâ â 415 ã. äî í.ý. Ðåçóëüòàòîì ýòîé êàìïàíèè ñòàëî ïîëíîå èñòðåáëåíèå àôèíñêîé àðìèè è ôëîòà. Â òå÷åíèå äåñÿòè ïîñëåäóþùèõ ëåò Àôèíû ïûòàëèñü ñîïðîòèâëÿòüñÿ, íî èõ ïîðàæåíèå áûëî íåèçáåæíî. Â 404 ã. äî í.ý. Àôèíû ñäàëèñü íà ìèëîñòü Ñïàðòû; òàêîâ áûë êîíåö àôèíñêîé èìïåðèè. [PARAGRAPH:1]Â òå÷åíèå ïîñëåäóþùèõ äåñÿòèëåòèé Àôèíû ñìîãëè âîññòàíîâèòüñÿ ïîñëå âîéí è ïîðàæåíèé, íî çîëîòîé âåê ãîðîäà ìèíîâàë, è áûëîå âåëè÷èå áûëî óòåðÿíî íàâñåãäà. Â 338 ã. äî í.ý. TEXT.English: [TAB]Athens is one of the great cities in world history. In ancient times its citizens made great contributions to many areas of politics, culture, and learning - including the virtual invention of philosophy, drama, science, and democracy. It can be argued that Athens has had the greatest influence of any city, state or empire on what is called, "Western Civilization." [PARAGRAPH:1]Humans have lived on the site of Athens since the Neolithic period (circa 4000 BC). According to tradition, the city-state (or "polis") of Athens was ruled by kings until roughly 1000 BC, after which it was governed by officials known as "archons," who were drawn from the ruling aristocracy. At first there were three archons, but six more were added later, bringing the total number of rulers to nine. Although originally reserved for the powerful ruling class, as time passed these offices were opened up to commoners. [PARAGRAPH:1]One archon, Solon, is credited with creating the famed Athenian democracy. Beginning in 594 BC, Solon implemented a series of liberal reforms that abolished serfdom, modified some of Athens' harsher laws, and removed some of the political restrictions on the city's economy. His reforms were so popular that Solon was subsequently given the task of rewriting Athens' constitution. While doing so, Solon significantly liberalized the Athenian government. creating a limited democracy which for the first time gave power to the non-aristocratic propertied classes. Throughout this period Athens continued to prosper and grow in size and influence. [PARAGRAPH:1]Some thirty years later, Athens' government was overthrown in a coup by a man named "Pisistratus." Though keeping many of Solon's reforms, Pisistratus ruled as a "tyrant," reserving the city-state's highest offices for friends and family. Pisistratus and his sons ruled Athens from 560-511 BC, until they were overthrown in turn by Cleisthenes, who restored Athens' limited democracy. Cleisthenes then expanded the democracy further, allowing all free Athenian men to participate in the government. Although women and slaves were still excluded from power, this was the most liberal - even radical - form of government yet seen in the world. [PARAGRAPH:1]In classical Athenian democracy, anyone (excluding women and slaves) was free to vote or serve a term in office. Most officials were chosen by lot, and government positions were rotated frequently. This was not always the most effective form of government, as it was quite common for people with no training whatsoever to find themselves elevated to positions of power and prestige, but under it the city-state thrived. [PARAGRAPH:1]As of 500 BC, much of Greece was thriving, and there were a number of successful city-states competing with Athens for primacy of the region. It wasn't until the Persian Wars of that century that Athens rose to preeminence. Athenian hoplites first fought and defeated a much larger Persian army at the Battle of Marathon in 492 BC. When the Persians returned a decade later with a much larger army, the united Greek armies were unable to halt the Persians' advance upon Athens. At the famous battle of Thermopylae, however, 300 Spartans sacrificed their lives to slow the Persians enough to allow the Athenians to evacuate their city, which the Persians subsequently entered and burned. [PARAGRAPH:1]Despite this grievous loss, the Athenian navy held firm, defeating the Persians at the Battle of Salamis in 480 BC. The combined Greek forces subsequently destroyed the invading armies and navies. As the war progressed Athens put together a loose confederation of polis, including most of the important island-based city-states, called the "Delian League," which brought the fight into Persia itself, eventually gaining the freedom of several important Greek colonies on the coast of Asia Minor and nearby islands. When the war ended the citizens of Athens returned to their city, and over the next years rebuilt it stronger and grander than ever before. In the following decades Athens became the cultural center of the Greek world. This was the golden age of the classical Athenian democracy, the era of famous figures such as Herodotus, Aeschylus, Sophocles, Euripides, and Socrates. [PARAGRAPH:1]During this period Athens became the dominant city-state in Greece. It possessed a lucrative trading empire, which was protected by its powerful navy, and it gradually transformed the Delian League into an empire, the other city-states in the League required to pay Athens tribute. This alarmed many of the other Greek polis, which, under the leadership of Sparta - the greatest land power in Greece - banded together in the "Spartan Alliance" to counter Athens' growing might. [PARAGRAPH:1]In 431 BC war broke out between the Delian League and the Spartan Alliance. commanded by Pericles, Athens' greatest statesman and general, Athens won numerous victories, but was unable to ever deliver the knockout blow needed to force the Spartans to surrender. Upon Pericles' death - from a plague that badly weakened Athens - command of the Athenian government and armed forces fell to less able hands, and the Athenians found themselves in a thirty-year war of attrition which grew ever more bitter and bloody as the years passed. [PARAGRAPH:1]Protected from direct assault by its Long Walls, and supplied by its offshore empire (inaccessible to the enemy), Athens survived the long war in fairly good shape (though its democratic institutions were gradually undermined). It is quite possible that Athens could have eventually forced its opponents into peace, if her people hadn't decided to send off a large portion of Athens' military forces on a foolish adventure of conquest to Sicily in 415 BC. During the campaign the Athenian army was obliterated, and its navy destroyed in detail. Though Athens continued to resist for some ten years, its defeat was inevitable. Athens finally surrendered to Sparta in 404 BC, its fleet in shambles and its overseas empire destroyed. [PARAGRAPH:1]Although Athens was able to recover briefly in the following decades, its golden age was past and it would never again reach the heights it attained before the disastrous war with Sparta. In 338 BC, Athens (along with the rest of Greece) was conquered by Philip of Macedon. The city would never again see independence, and Greece would spend most of the next 2,000 years under foreign rule - governed in turn by Macedonia, Rome, Byzantium, and the Ottoman Empire. In 1829 AD Greece would finally win independence - and Athens was naturally chosen as the new state's capital city.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The "Title" civic is a game mechanic that is used to track Alexander's legendary status. As the unit Alexander is attached to gains levels, Alexander will gain better "Titles." The better Alexander's "Title", the easier it will be to rule a large nation. [PARAGRAPH:1]If the unit Alexander is attached to should ever die, Alexander's "Title" will revert back the worst title until Alexander has healed from his wounds and is reattached to a unit.

TEXT.English: Sited around the Ohio River, vacant of humanity for nearly 100 years and thus densely populated with game, tensions between New France and Britain are escalating. Between this approaching storm, nearly 3,000 Shawnee and Lenape Indians have found commercial success in trading fur for weapons and other goods.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]While the unfolding events may differ from historical ones, as Governor of New France or an investigating 21 year old Major of the British military, your actions will be one of the many factors which ignite a massive international conflict.
